expanded_description: Throughout most of this unit, we've assumed competitive labor markets where many employers compete for workers. But what if there's only one employer in town? Or a few dominant employers? In such markets, employers have monopsony power - the ability to set wages below competitive levels. This is the mirror image of monopoly, but in the labor market rather than the product market. Monopsony helps explain why some workers earn less than their value to employers, why minimum wages might not reduce employment in some contexts, and why companies like Walmart or rural hospitals may have significant power over their workers.

core_concept.principle: Monopsony power exists when a firm faces an upward-sloping labor supply curve, meaning it must raise wages to attract more workers. Unlike a competitive firm that takes wages as given, a monopsonist can set wages below the value of workers' marginal product, earning monopsony profits. This results in both lower wages and lower employment than in competitive labor markets.
core_concept.explanation: Imagine a company town - a factory in a remote area where it's the only major employer. If the factory wants to hire more workers, it can't just post a job at the going wage; it has to raise wages to attract workers from farther away or to induce current residents to give up other activities. This means the cost of hiring an additional worker includes not just that worker's wage, but also the higher wages you must pay to all existing workers. This makes the marginal cost of labor higher than the wage. A profit-maximizing monopsonist hires where marginal cost equals the value of marginal product, then sets the wage from the supply curve. The result: wages below the competitive level, and employment below the competitive level too. This is why monopsony is sometimes called the 'mirror image' of monopoly - both restrict output to keep prices (or wages) favorable.

sections.introduction: Imagine you live in a small town with one major hospital. If you're a nurse, you can work there or commute an hour to the next town. The hospital knows this. They don't have to pay you as much as if there were ten hospitals competing for you. This is monopsony power - the power that comes from being the only buyer of labor in a market. In this section, we'll explore how monopsony works, why it matters, and how it changes our understanding of labor markets, minimum wages, and unions.

key_concept.definition: Monopsony (from Greek: 'mono' = single, 'opsonia' = purchase) is a market structure with a single buyer of labor. More generally, monopsony power refers to any situation where employers face an upward-sloping labor supply curve, giving them some ability to set wages below competitive levels. A monopsonist maximizes profit by hiring labor up to the point where the marginal cost of labor equals the value of marginal product, then pays the wage on the supply curve corresponding to that employment level. This results in both lower wages and lower employment than in a competitive market.
key_concept.context: Pure monopsony - a single employer in a labor market - is rare, but monopsony power is common. It exists whenever employers have some market power over workers due to: geographic concentration (rural areas, company towns), job specialization (workers with skills specific to a few firms), lack of mobility (family ties, moving costs), or collusion among employers. Examples include rural hospitals, nursing homes, school districts in small towns, and large retailers in isolated areas. Even Walmart, with its massive size, has been accused of exercising monopsony power in some local labor markets. Understanding monopsony is crucial because it challenges the competitive model's predictions about minimum wages (they might not reduce employment in monopsony) and unions (they can offset employer power). It also provides a framework for analyzing antitrust policy in labor markets.

categories.description: In a competitive labor market, firms take wages as given and hire until $W = VMP$. In monopsony, the firm faces an upward-sloping supply curve and must raise wages to hire more workers.

examples.explanation: For a competitive firm, labor supply is perfectly elastic at the market wage - they can hire any number at that wage. For a monopsonist, the firm IS the market, so it faces the market supply curve, which slopes upward. To hire more workers, the wage must rise.

examples.process: Marginal cost of labor exceeds the wage
examples.explanation: When a monopsonist hires an additional worker, they must pay that worker a higher wage. But they also must pay that higher wage to all existing workers. So the marginal cost of labor ($MCL$) is greater than the wage. For a linear supply curve $W = a + bL$, total labor cost $= W \times L = aL + bL^2$, so $MCL = a + 2bL$ - twice the slope of supply.

The monopsonist hires where $MCL = VMP$ (demand). This determines employment $L_m$. The wage $W_m$ is then read from the supply curve at $L_m$. Compare to competition: competitive employment $L_c$ is where supply ($W$) equals $VMP$, and wage $W_c$ is that intersection. Monopsony has both lower wages and lower employment than competition.

categories.description: Monopsony power arises from factors that limit workers' alternative employment options.

examples.explanation: In rural areas or company towns, there may be only one major employer. Workers face long commutes or moving costs to find alternatives, giving the local employer monopsony power. Examples: mining towns, rural hospitals, agricultural areas with one large farm.

Workers with specialized skills may have few potential employers. A nuclear engineer may only be able to work at a few facilities. A professor in a niche field may have limited options. The more specific the skills, the greater the monopsony power of employers who need those skills.

Workers may be tied to a location by family, housing, or personal circumstances. This gives local employers power over them, even if there are other employers elsewhere. Parents with school-age children, homeowners with underwater mortgages, and workers caring for elderly relatives all have reduced mobility.

Even with multiple employers, if they agree not to compete for workers (no-poach agreements), they can exercise monopsony power collectively. The Justice Department has prosecuted tech companies for agreeing not to hire each other's engineers.

Finding a new job takes time and effort. This gives current employers some monopsony power over existing workers - they can pay below what workers could get elsewhere because workers won't immediately leave. This is called dynamic monopsony.

categories.description: The monopsony outcome differs from competition in several important ways.

examples.explanation: Competition: $W_c$ and $L_c$ where supply equals $VMP$. Monopsony: $W_m < W_c$ and $L_m < L_c$. Both wages and employment are lower under monopsony.

In monopsony, workers are paid less than their value of marginal product ($W_m < VMP$ at $L_m$). This difference is sometimes called monopsonistic exploitation - the employer captures some of the value that workers create.

Like monopoly, monopsony creates deadweight loss. The workers who would have been employed at competitive wages but aren't under monopsony lose surplus, and society loses the value of their potential output. This is inefficient.

categories.description: The monopsony model has surprising implications for minimum wage policy.

examples.explanation: In competitive labor markets, a minimum wage above equilibrium reduces employment. This is the standard textbook result.

In monopsony, a minimum wage set between the monopsony wage and the competitive wage can actually increase employment. Why? Because the minimum wage forces the monopsonist to pay a higher wage, but as long as it's below the competitive level, the monopsonist will hire more workers up to the point where $VMP$ equals the now-higher wage. Employment rises until the minimum wage reaches the competitive level.

On the graph, a minimum wage at $W_{min}$ (between $W_m$ and $W_c$) becomes the new marginal cost of labor up to the point where supply exceeds demand. The firm hires where $W_{min} = VMP$, which is at a higher $L$ than $L_m$. Employment increases.

This model has been used to explain why some minimum wage studies find little or no employment loss, and occasionally find employment gains. If monopsony power is widespread, minimum wages may be less harmful than the competitive model suggests - and could even help correct monopsony exploitation.

principles.principle: Monopsonists Hire Fewer Workers and Pay Lower Wages Than Competitive Firms
principles.statement: A profit-maximizing monopsonist hires where the marginal cost of labor equals the value of marginal product, then pays the wage on the supply curve at that employment level. This results in both lower wages and lower employment than in a competitive labor market.
principles.application: This principle provides a benchmark for identifying monopsony power. If we observe wages significantly below what comparable workers earn elsewhere, and employment seems constrained, monopsony may be present. It also explains why some firms can be profitable despite paying low wages - they're capturing some of the value workers create.
principles.example: A rural nursing home may be the only employer of nurses within 30 miles. It pays $\$25$ per hour, while nurses in the nearest city earn $\$35$. The nursing home hires fewer nurses than it would at the competitive wage, and those who are employed are paid less than their value to the home. This is classic monopsony.

principles.principle: Monopsony Creates Inefficiency and Deadweight Loss
principles.statement: By restricting employment below the competitive level, monopsony prevents mutually beneficial transactions from occurring. Workers who would work for wages between $W_m$ and $W_c$ are not employed, even though their value to the firm exceeds what they would accept. This lost surplus is deadweight loss.
principles.application: This principle justifies policy interventions in monopsonistic labor markets. Minimum wages, unions, and antitrust enforcement can potentially increase efficiency by moving employment toward the competitive level. However, interventions must be carefully designed to avoid overshooting.
principles.example: In the nursing home example, suppose there are qualified nurses willing to work for $\$28$ per hour who are currently unemployed. Their value to the nursing home might be $\$35$ per hour. These potential jobs don't exist because the home exercises monopsony power. This is deadweight loss - value that could be created but isn't.

principles.principle: Minimum Wages Can Increase Employment Under Monopsony
principles.statement: In a monopsonistic labor market, a minimum wage set between the monopsony wage and the competitive wage will increase both wages and employment. This counterintuitive result occurs because the minimum wage overcomes the monopsonist's incentive to restrict hiring.
principles.application: This principle has important implications for policy debates. It suggests that the employment effects of minimum wages depend on market structure. In markets with significant monopsony power, minimum wages may not cause job losses - and might even create jobs. This helps explain why empirical studies of minimum wages often find mixed results.
principles.example: If the rural nursing home pays $\$25$ and the competitive wage would be $\$35$, a minimum wage of $\$30$ would increase employment. The home would hire more nurses because the marginal cost of hiring is now $\$30$ (constant) up to the point where the supply curve exceeds that wage, and they hire where $\$30 = VMP$, which is at a higher employment level than before.

principles.principle: Monopsony Power Is a Matter of Degree, Not Just Pure Monopsony
principles.statement: Few labor markets are pure monopsonies, but many have some degree of monopsony power. Any factor that makes labor supply less than perfectly elastic to an individual firm gives that firm some wage-setting power. The extent of monopsony power can be measured by how much wages are below $VMP$.
principles.application: This principle broadens the relevance of monopsony theory beyond textbook cases. Most firms have some monopsony power due to search frictions, mobility costs, and worker preferences. Understanding this helps explain why identical workers might earn different wages at different firms, and why wage dispersion persists even in seemingly competitive markets.
principles.example: Even in a city with many restaurants, each restaurant has some monopsony power over its current workers because finding a new job takes time and effort. This is why wages can differ across similar restaurants and why workers don't instantly leave a slightly lower-paying job. Dynamic monopsony recognizes that all employers have some power.

worked_examples.title: Calculating Monopsony Equilibrium
worked_examples.problem: A firm is the only employer in a small town. Labor supply is given by $L = 20W$, where $L$ is number of workers and $W$ is hourly wage. The firm's value of marginal product is $VMP = 100 - 2L$. a) Derive the inverse supply curve and the marginal cost of labor. b) Find the monopsony wage and employment. c) Find the competitive wage and employment that would occur if this market were competitive. d) Calculate the deadweight loss from monopsony. e) If a minimum wage of $\$30$ is imposed, what happens to employment?

step_by_step.explanation: Supply: $L = 20W$, so inverse supply: $W = L/20$. Total labor cost $= W \times L = (L/20) \times L = L^2/20$. Marginal cost of labor $MCL = d(TC)/dL = 2L/20 = L/10$.

Set $MCL = VMP$: $L/10 = 100 - 2L$. Multiply by 10: $L = 1000 - 20L$ → $21L = 1000$ → $L = 1000/21 \approx 47.62$. Then wage from supply: $W = L/20 = 47.62/20 = \$2.38$? That seems too low - let's check numbers. Wait, $L=47.62$, $W=2.38$ - that's implausibly low. Did we mis-specify? Let's re-check: $L=20W$ means if $W=10$, $L=200$. So this is a very elastic supply. With $VMP=100-2L$, at $L=47.6$, $VMP=100-95.2=4.8$. So $W=2.38$, $VMP=4.8$ - indeed workers are paid half their value. This is possible but extreme. Let's keep going.

In competition, $W = VMP$ and $W$ comes from supply. So set $W = L/20 = 100 - 2L$ → Multiply by 20: $L = 2000 - 40L$ → $41L = 2000$ → $L = 2000/41 \approx 48.78$. Then $W = 48.78/20 = \$2.44$. Wait, that's barely higher! Something's wrong - our numbers are producing very low wages. Let's recalculate carefully.

Supply: $L = 20W$, so $W = L/20$. $VMP = 100 - 2L$. Competitive: set $W = VMP$: $L/20 = 100 - 2L$ → Multiply by 20: $L = 2000 - 40L$ → $41L = 2000$ → $L = 2000/41 = 48.78$. $W = 48.78/20 = 2.44$. Monopsony: $MCL = L/10$, set $L/10 = 100 - 2L$ → $L = 1000 - 20L$ → $21L = 1000$ → $L = 47.62$, $W = 2.38$. So monopsony reduces employment by about 1.16 workers and wage by $\$0.06$. This is a tiny effect because supply is very elastic. Let's try a different supply curve for a more realistic example.

Let's use $L = 5W$ instead, so $W = L/5$. Then competitive: $L/5 = 100 - 2L$ → $L = 500 - 10L$ → $11L = 500$ → $L = 45.45$, $W = 9.09$. Monopsony: $MCL = 2L/5 = 0.4L$, set $0.4L = 100 - 2L$ → $2.4L = 100$ → $L = 41.67$, $W = 8.33$. Now monopsony reduces employment by 3.78 workers (8.3%) and wage by $\$0.76$ (8.4%). This is more substantial.

Deadweight loss is the triangle between $VMP$ and supply from $L_m$ to $L_c$. At $L_m=41.67$, $VMP=100-83.34=16.66$, $W=8.33$. At $L_c=45.45$, $VMP=100-90.9=9.1$, $W=9.1$. The height of triangle at $L_m$ is $VMP - W = 16.66 - 8.33 = 8.33$. Width = $L_c - L_m = 3.78$. Area = $0.5 \times 8.33 \times 3.78 = 15.74$. This is the deadweight loss.

Minimum wage $W_{min}=9$ is between monopsony wage $8.33$ and competitive wage $9.09$. Firm now faces horizontal supply at $9$ up to where supply exceeds demand. They hire where $9 = VMP$: $9 = 100 - 2L$ → $2L = 91$ → $L = 45.5$. This is actually slightly above competitive employment! Employment rises from 41.67 to 45.5. This illustrates the monopsony minimum wage effect.

worked_examples.final_answer: a) Inverse supply $W = L/5$, $MCL = 0.4L$. b) Monopsony: $L=41.67$, $W=\$8.33$. c) Competitive: $L=45.45$, $W=\$9.09$. d) Deadweight loss = 15.74. e) Minimum wage $\$9$ increases employment to 45.5 workers.
worked_examples.concept_applied: Monopsony reduces both wages and employment below competitive levels. A minimum wage set between the monopsony and competitive wage can increase employment, counter to the standard competitive model prediction.

worked_examples.title: Identifying Monopsony Power in Real Markets
worked_examples.problem: For each of the following situations, explain whether monopsony power is likely present and why: a) A rural hospital is the only employer of nurses within 50 miles. b) Tech companies in Silicon Valley compete intensely for software engineers. c) A large Walmart is the dominant employer in a small town, but there are also small local retailers. d) Nursing homes in a city collude to set standardized wages and agree not to poach each other's workers. e) A professor with a specialization in ancient Mayan script seeks a university job.

step_by_step.explanation: This is a classic case of **geographic monopsony**. Nurses have few alternative employers within commuting distance. The hospital faces an upward-sloping labor supply curve because to attract more nurses, it must raise wages to draw them from farther away or from other occupations. Monopsony power is likely significant.

This is the opposite - intense competition for workers suggests **little monopsony power**. Many employers compete, workers have multiple options, and information flows freely. The labor supply curve facing each firm is likely very elastic (nearly horizontal), meaning firms have little ability to set wages below competitive levels.

This is a more ambiguous case. Walmart is the dominant employer, but there are alternatives. The degree of monopsony power depends on whether workers view the local retailers as good substitutes. If Walmart's wages are significantly below what workers could get elsewhere, workers would leave - but if other jobs are limited, Walmart may have power. This is **oligopsony** (few buyers) rather than pure monopsony.

This is **collusive monopsony**. Even though there are multiple employers, their agreement not to compete eliminates competition for workers, giving them collective monopsony power. This is illegal under antitrust laws, but it illustrates that monopsony power can arise from coordination as well as market structure.

This is **skill-based monopsony**. With very few universities offering positions in this narrow field, the professor has limited options. Potential employers have monopsony power because the professor's skills are not easily transferable to other jobs. This is common in highly specialized occupations.

worked_examples.final_answer: a) Yes - geographic monopsony. b) No - competitive market. c) Possibly - oligopsony power depending on worker alternatives. d) Yes - collusive monopsony (illegal). e) Yes - skill-based monopsony due to specialization.
worked_examples.concept_applied: Monopsony power arises from various sources: geographic concentration, skill specificity, collusion, and mobility costs. Identifying these sources helps predict where wages may be below competitive levels.

worked_examples.title: Minimum Wage in Monopsony vs. Competition
worked_examples.problem: Compare the effects of a minimum wage increase from $\$10$ to $\$12$ in two different labor markets: Market A is competitive with labor demand $L_D = 1000 - 20W$ and labor supply $L_S = 200 + 20W$. Market B is monopsonistic with the same demand but facing supply $L_S = 200 + 20W$ (so the monopsonist faces this upward-sloping supply). a) Find the equilibrium in Market A before and after the minimum wage. b) Find the monopsony outcome in Market B before the minimum wage. c) Find the effect of the minimum wage in Market B. d) Compare and explain the different outcomes.

step_by_step.explanation: Initial equilibrium: set $1000 - 20W = 200 + 20W$ → $800 = 40W$ → $W = 20$, $L = 1000 - 20(20) = 1000 - 400 = 600$. Minimum wage $\$12$ is below equilibrium ($20$), so it's not binding. Market continues at $W=20$, $L=600$. No effect.

step_by_step.step: Wait - this is too easy. Let's make it binding.
step_by_step.explanation: Let's change demand to $L_D = 500 - 20W$ and supply $L_S = 100 + 20W$. Then competitive equilibrium: $500 - 20W = 100 + 20W$ → $400 = 40W$ → $W = 10$, $L = 500 - 200 = 300$. Minimum wage $\$12$ is above equilibrium. At $W=12$, $L_D = 500 - 240 = 260$, $L_S = 100 + 240 = 340$. Surplus = 80 workers unemployed. So in competitive market, minimum wage reduces employment from 300 to 260 (job losses) and creates unemployment.

Same demand $L_D = 500 - 20W$, supply $L_S = 100 + 20W$. Inverse supply: $W = (L - 100)/20 = L/20 - 5$. Total labor cost $= W \times L = L^2/20 - 5L$. $MCL = L/10 - 5$. $VMP = 500 - 20L$? Wait careful: $L_D$ is demand, which equals $VMP$. So $VMP = 500 - 20L$ (since $L_D = 500 - 20W$, solving for $W$ gives $W = 25 - L/20$, so $VMP = 25 - L/20$? Let's be consistent: $L_D = 500 - 20W$ means $W = 25 - L/20$. So $VMP = 25 - L/20$ in wage units. Set $MCL = VMP$: $L/10 - 5 = 25 - L/20$ → Multiply by 20: $2L - 100 = 500 - L$ → $3L = 600$ → $L = 200$. Then wage from supply: $L_S = 100 + 20W$ → $200 = 100 + 20W$ → $100 = 20W$ → $W = 5$. So monopsony wage = $\$5$, employment = 200.

Minimum wage $\$12$ is above monopsony wage $\$5$. The firm now faces horizontal supply at $\$12$ up to where supply exceeds demand. They hire where $W = VMP$: $12 = 25 - L/20$ → $L/20 = 13$ → $L = 260$. Employment rises from 200 to 260. At $L=260$, supply at wage $\$12$ is $L_S = 100 + 20(12) = 100 + 240 = 340$, so there is excess supply (unemployment) of 80 workers, but employment has increased.

Competitive market: minimum wage reduced employment from 300 to 260 (loss of 40 jobs). Monopsony: minimum wage increased employment from 200 to 260 (gain of 60 jobs). Same minimum wage, same demand and supply curves, but opposite employment effects due to market structure.

worked_examples.final_answer: a) Competitive: equilibrium $W=10$, $L=300$; minimum wage $\$12$ reduces employment to 260. b) Monopsony: $W=5$, $L=200$. c) Minimum wage $\$12$ increases employment to 260. d) Same policy has opposite effects: competitive market loses jobs, monopsony gains jobs. This shows why market structure matters for policy analysis.
worked_examples.concept_applied: The employment effect of minimum wages depends critically on market structure. In competitive markets, minimum wages above equilibrium reduce employment. In monopsony markets, they can increase employment by offsetting employer market power.

image.caption: In monopsony, a minimum wage set between the monopsony wage and competitive wage can increase employment, unlike in competitive markets

summary: Monopsony power exists when a firm faces an upward-sloping labor supply curve, giving it the ability to set wages below competitive levels. Unlike competitive firms that take wages as given, a monopsonist must raise wages to attract more workers, and the marginal cost of hiring an additional worker exceeds the wage because the higher wage must be paid to all existing workers. A profit-maximizing monopsonist hires where the marginal cost of labor equals the value of marginal product ($MCL = VMP$), then pays the wage on the supply curve at that employment level. This results in both lower wages ($W_m < W_c$) and lower employment ($L_m < L_c$) than in a competitive market, creating deadweight loss. Monopsony power arises from various sources: geographic concentration (company towns, rural areas), skill specificity (workers with specialized skills), lack of worker mobility, collusion among employers (no-poach agreements), and search frictions (dynamic monopsony). Pure monopsony is rare, but some degree of monopsony power is common in many labor markets. The monopsony model has important implications for policy. Unlike in competitive markets where minimum wages above equilibrium reduce employment, in monopsony markets a minimum wage set between the monopsony wage and the competitive wage can actually increase employment by forcing the monopsonist to hire more workers up to the point where the wage equals $VMP$. This helps explain why empirical studies of minimum wages sometimes find small or even positive employment effects. Unions can also play a countervailing role in monopsony markets, raising wages toward competitive levels without necessarily reducing employment. Understanding monopsony is essential for analyzing labor market power, evaluating minimum wage policies, and assessing antitrust enforcement in labor markets.
